guide.conclusion: My 4-8 hour time estimate is assuming you're working hard, maybe have a helper and are in a rush to get this thing done before Halloween. It helps, but isn't necessary, to have a general idea of basic carpentry (e.g., cutting a piece of wood and nailing it to another piece of wood).

guide.introduction:
At the last minute this Halloween we decided to decorate in a creepy carnival theme with the goal of not spending too much money on decorations to save more for candy.

One of the many ideas we had was to build a creepy ticket booth to welcome visitors to our house for Trick or Treat.

This 'back of a napkin' idea evolved into a recycling mission as we scoured the industrial park for old, weather-beaten pallets and dug through flea market bins for door hinges.

Everything about this project was very freestyle and design-as-you-build but I'll do my best to nail down specifics so you can recreate this ticket booth for yourself.

There are a LOT of steps here because I like to be as thorough as possible. I'll keep it as concise as I can.

Also important to note, some pictures will differ slightly from my instructions. This is by no means a 'to-the-inch' guide. If I made 5 of these I guarantee they'd be a little different every time. Feel free to wing it a little.
guide.introduction_rendered:
At the last minute this Halloween we decided to decorate in a creepy carnival theme with the goal of not spending too much money on decorations to save more for candy.

One of the many ideas we had was to build a creepy ticket booth to welcome visitors to our house for Trick or Treat.

This 'back of a napkin' idea evolved into a recycling mission as we scoured the industrial park for old, weather-beaten pallets and dug through flea market bins for door hinges.

Everything about this project was very freestyle and design-as-you-build but I'll do my best to nail down specifics so you can recreate this ticket booth for yourself.

There are a LOT of steps here because I like to be as thorough as possible. I'll keep it as concise as I can.

Also important to note, some pictures will differ slightly from my instructions. This is by no means a 'to-the-inch' guide. If I made 5 of these I guarantee they'd be a little different every time. Feel free to wing it a little.

Relevant parts
  • Screws
  • Nails
  • Shipping Pallet
  • Door Hinges
  • Paint
  • Christmas lights
  • 1/2" PVC pipe, 10' length
Tools
  • 3/4" boring bit
  • Air compressor
  • Electric or Hand Saw
  • Hack saw
  • Paintbrush
  • Pneumatic nailer
  • Prybar or Crowbar
  • Rag
  • Screw gun
  • Tape measure

parts.notes: You can do this with nails or screws though I recommend nails and a pneumatic nailer.
finish nails approx 1.5-2 inches in length for your pneumatic nailer
Get plenty of shipping pallets. You'll be using mostly the top planks so the older looking (but not cracked) the better. You could also use old 'dogear' wood fence that's been outside.
Any old door hinges will do. Check Goodwill, building salvage stores and old men's yard sales.

Depending on your color scheme or design, you'll want to have some latex or acrylic paint. Spray paint won't work well on this project unless you want to spray it into a cup and brush it on. Your call.
Pick up a strand of Christmas lights. Preferably the old style kind (C7 or C9). You only need enough to light your sign if you decide to make one.
Use PVC for the window bars. OPTIONAL: Use metal electrical conduit instead of PVC.

lines.text: If you choose to use old shipping pallets like I did for your ticket booth you can do a quick search on Craigslist in your area to find a company giving them away or just drive around your local industrial area and ask nicely.

lines.text: I used a pneumatic nailer which I recommend. You will need a few various lengths of nails or staples as well as some nail-cutting pliers to snip any nails that happen to poke through the other side.

lines.text_raw: Use a piece of cardboard or paper the same size as your plywood and  fold it in half, then unfold it. Sketch out the shape of your sign using the crease line as your center line. (you will only need half of your sketch.

lines.text_raw: Cut out your paper/cardboard shape around the outline and along the center line.

lines.text: Place the half-template on your plywood and trace the outline, flipping it over to trace the other half of the sign. Ahhhhh, symmetry.
lines.text_raw: Place the half-template on your plywood and trace the outline, flipping it over to trace the other half of the sign. Ahhhhh, symmetry.

lines.text: Using the scary jigsaw, cut out the sign around the shape outline you just made.
lines.text_raw: Using the scary jigsaw, cut out the sign around the shape outline you just made.

lines.text: Separate the pieces and trace a line around the inside of one of the pieces to create a 2" border. Using the jigsaw, with a plunge cut or by drilling a pilot hole, cut out the inner area of the border.
lines.text_raw: Separate the pieces and trace a line around the inside of one of the pieces to create a 2" border. Using the jigsaw, with a plunge cut or by drilling a pilot hole, cut out the inner area of the border.

lines.text: Nail the sign border to the sign backing panel.
lines.text_raw: Nail the sign border to the sign backing panel.

lines.text: Yep, that's it for this step.
lines.text_raw: Yep, that's it for this step.

lines.text: Based on your color scheme, paint the border and base accordingly using the technique outlined in previous steps. Use multiple coats of watered-down paint until you achieve the weathered look you're going for.
lines.text_raw: Based on your color scheme, paint the border and base accordingly using the technique outlined in previous steps. Use multiple coats of watered-down paint until you achieve the weathered look you're going for.

lines.text: To create the letters you can use any font. I chose to use an older style font similar to those used in wood-type letterpress printing.
lines.text_raw: To create the letters you can use any font. I chose to use an older style font similar to those used in wood-type letterpress printing.

lines.text: Visit DaFont.com to browse through thousands of fonts and choose the one you like for your sign.
lines.text_raw: Visit [http://www.dafont.com|DaFont.com] to browse through thousands of fonts and choose the one you like for your sign.

lines.text: Install your font and use a program like Photoshop, Illustrator, or a word processor to type out your sign lettering. Most of these programs have a tool which allows you to shape your text within an arc as shown in the attached photo.
lines.text_raw: Install your font and use a program like Photoshop, Illustrator, or a word processor to type out your sign lettering. Most of these programs have a tool which allows you to shape your text within an arc as shown in the attached photo.

lines.text: Measure the available space on your sign, allowing for some space around the edges of the letters, and use that measurement to scale your font accordingly in the program you are using.
lines.text_raw: Measure the available space on your sign, allowing for some space around the edges of the letters, and use that measurement to scale your font accordingly in the program you are using.

lines.text: Most printers allow you to print large images across multple pages which can be taped together to create a large printed image to transfer to your sign.
lines.text_raw: Most printers allow you to print large images across multple pages which can be taped together to create a large printed image to transfer to your sign.

lines.text: Using a graphite transfer paper or equivalent (anyone remember carbon paper?) trace the sign lettering onto the sign and paint in your letters using the watered-down paint method. Take your time here; lettering can really 'make' the sign.

lines.text: Decide how far apart you want to place your lights.
lines.text_raw: Decide how far apart you want to place your lights.

lines.text: Locate the center of your sign and place a pencil mark there to help you equally space the light bulbs on your sign. Place X marks centered within the border around the entire sign to mark the positions of the light bulbs.

lines.text: If you want to add a skull to the top of your sign like I did, just be sure to leave a space for the skull as shown. If you use a blow-mold hollow skull you can put a light inside the skull to make the skull glow as well. I didn't.

lines.text: Starting from the plug end of your light string, place the first socket into the lower left or right corner hole depending on where you wish to run your light string wiring into the booth.
lines.text_raw: Starting from the plug end of your light string, place the first socket into the lower left or right corner hole depending on where you wish to run your light string wiring into the booth.

lines.text: Work your way around the sign inserting sockets into the holes. When you reach the last hole simply cut the string wire 3-6 inches from the last socket and seal off this cut end with electrical tape or shrink wrap.

lines.text: Using a staple gun, attach all loose wire to the back of the sign to keep things nice and tidy.

lines.text: Install your bulbs, plug it in and let there be LIGHT!
